text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column page with two horizontally framed narrative registers separated by a thin divider line; text block above and below the image panels; visual hierarchy gives central prominence to the paired scenes

text_content.script_style: Gothic textualis quadrata with angular, compressed letterforms and occasional decorative flourishes

color_scheme.color_usage: Flat washes distinguish roles: red for martyrs’ robes and flames, green and yellow for attendant tunics; minimal shading or highlighting; palette consistent across both registers; color serves narrative clarity rather than hierarchical gold; limited earth tones harmonize the scenes

decorative_elements: Simple rectangular framing lines around each narrative register

drawing_technique.line_style: Uniform brown ink contours with minimal variation in weight
drawing_technique.shading_method: No hatch or tonal shading; color applied as flat washes
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: No linear perspective; figures aligned on a common baseline; scale determined by narrative role rather than spatial depth

scene_relationships.subject: King pronouncing sentence on three bound martyrs while attendant holds upright sword
visual_connections: Red robes on martyrs echo in both registers
Brown ink outlines and flat washes consistent

scene_relationships.subject: Executioner raises sword over three martyrs whose necks are affixed to a wooden beam with flames at stumps
visual_connections: King retains same posture and costume
Color scheme repeats (red robes, green/yellow tunics)
Curly hair motifs on all figures repeated

content_theme.scene_description: Top register: A crowned king in yellow-ochre tunic and red cloak sits left on a simple bench, drapery folds indicated by parallel lines. To his right stands an attendant in verdigris-green knee-length tunic, holding an oversized upright sword by its pommel. Three bound martyrs in long red robes lean forward on the right; stylized flames issue from their severed neck stumps. All figures share a single horizontal ground line within a thin rectangular frame. Bottom register: The king repeats on the left, seated identically. In the center, an executioner in yellow ochre tunic raises his sword above three martyrs bound together by a horizontal wooden beam at their necks, flames again depicted at the stumps. Victims wear alternating red and green robes, curly hair rendered as small loops. Scale is uniform; spatial depth is implied only by overlapping limbs and repeated ground line. Costumes lack intricate pattern but show status through color. The sequence moves from judicial condemnation (top) to execution (bottom), underscoring the martyrdom theme.

religious: Three martyrs depicted with curly hair, bound hands, red robes and flaming neck stumps
secular: King: crowned, seated in yellow and red robes
Executioner/attendant: green and yellow knee-length tunics, bare legs
symbolic: Flames at neck stumps symbolizing martyrdom
Sword as emblem of royal justice

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual devotional reader or small monastic community

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This two-register illumination likely originates from a 13th-century Western European workshop specializing in hagiographic compilations. The absence of luxurious pigments such as ultramarine and gold leaf suggests a moderately endowed commission, perhaps for a private patron or a minor religious house. The use of flat color washes—minium red, verdigris green, and yellow ochre—combined with uniform brown ink outlines aligns with itinerant workshop practices that prioritized narrative clarity over opulent display. The depiction of the king’s stylized throne area and the attendant’s oversized sword underscores royal authority enforcing divine justice; the flaming neck stumps signal the martyrs’ sanctity and their passage from temporal judgment to heavenly reward. The repetition of gestures, color schemes, and framing devices across both registers creates a cohesive visual program illustrating condemnation followed by execution. Paleographically, the Latin text in Gothic textualis quadrata indicates a mature high-medieval scriptoria environment where book production was increasingly standardized. Iconographically, the scene contributes to a theological motif linking earthly authority and martyrdom, reflecting contemporary devotional emphases on suffering and witness. Compared to contemporaneous manuscripts such as the Bury Bible or certain French psalters, this illumination is relatively austere but effective in its didactic narrative sequencing, aligning it with modest devotional books of saints’ lives rather than grand liturgical manuscripts.
